title: LinkLetter
content:
[http://www.educationalfontware.com/HB\_style.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20130529064103/http:/www.educationalfontware.com/HB_style.html "http://www.educationalfontware.com/HB\_style.html")

"When you type using a cursive font, some of the letters aren't linked...All you have to do to get the proper connections is to run the LinkLetter program we supply you--after you have finished your typing."

What is this "auto-join" software? Anyone have details, or used it?
author: Brian_

comments.content: I think it only works with their fonts.

Some cursive font makers (for example Signature Software) map the alternate cursive forms to upper ASCII characters (eg all those accented characters) they then use a macro to switch these alternates into a passage of text. Apart from being a bit of a hack, the text is not searchable or cut and paste-able, and if you switch fonts becomes gibberish. Another reason why OpenType is a better bet.

Si

The Cursive handwriting font requires individual characters to have multiple beginning and ending strokes depending on the character pair combination used in a word. Around 1992 I designed and developed the typefaces for Zaner-Bloser Publishing who had the original drawing. Because the character set was limited I developed several font and a colleague designed a custom application to switch fonts on the fly. I assume this application is very similar.  
Your right Si, OpenType would have made the project more interactive.

Yes, font-switching would provide more accessible results - cut and paste and search would likely work. I made this IE font embedding demo a few years back which used that technique.

details - [http://www.microsoft.com/typography/web/embedding/demos/8/about8.htm](http://web.archive.org/web/20130529064103/http:/www.microsoft.com/typography/web/embedding/demos/8/about8.htm "http://www.microsoft.com/typography/web/embedding/demos/8/about8.htm")
